remarks.format:
## Remarks The default implementation of this asynchronous method delegates to its synchronous counterpart and returns a completed `Task`, potentially blocking the calling thread.
Data providers that support [asynchronous programming](/dotnet/framework/data/adonet/asynchronous-programming) should override the default implementation using asynchronous I/O operations.

Docs.summary: Releases all resources used by the current instance of the class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Call `Dispose` or `DisposeAsync` when you've finished using the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader>. Calling one of these methods leaves the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader> in an unusable state. After disposing, you must release all references to the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader> so the garbage collector can reclaim the memory that the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader> was occupying.
For more information, see [Cleaning Up Unmanaged Resources](/dotnet/standard/garbage-collection/unmanaged) and [Implementing a Dispose Method](/dotnet/standard/garbage-collection/implementing-dispose).
> [!NOTE] > Always dispose before you release your last reference to the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader>. Otherwise, the resources it is using will not be freed until the garbage collector calls the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader> object's `Finalize` method.

protected: virtual void Dispose(bool disposing);

Docs.param: to release managed and unmanaged resources; to release only unmanaged resources.
Docs.summary: Releases the unmanaged resources used by the and optionally releases the managed resources.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This method calls <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader.Close%2A>.

Docs.returns: A representing the asynchronous operation.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Call `Dispose` or `DisposeAsync` when you've finished using the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader>. Calling one of these methods leaves the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader> in an unusable state. After disposing, you must release all references to the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader> so the garbage collector can reclaim the memory that the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader> was occupying.
For more information, see [Cleaning Up Unmanaged Resources](/dotnet/standard/garbage-collection/unmanaged) and [Implementing a Dispose Method](/dotnet/standard/garbage-collection/implementing-dispose).
> [!NOTE] > Always dispose before you release your last reference to the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader>. Otherwise, the resources it is using will not be freed until the garbage collector calls the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader> object's `Finalize` method.
The default implementation of this asynchronous method delegates to its synchronous counterpart and returns a completed `ValueTask`, potentially blocking the calling thread.
Data providers that support [asynchronous programming](/dotnet/framework/data/adonet/asynchronous-programming) should override the default implementation using asynchronous I/O operations.

Docs.summary: This is the asynchronous version of . Providers should override with an appropriate implementation. The can optionally be honored. The default implementation invokes the synchronous call and returns a completed task. The default implementation will return a cancelled task if passed an already cancelled . Exceptions thrown by will be communicated via the returned Task Exception property.
Docs.returns: A task representing the asynchronous operation.

Docs.summary: When overridden in a derived class, returns an enumerator that can be used to iterate through the rows in the data reader.
Docs.returns: An enumerator that can be used to iterate through the rows in the data reader.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Although you can use this method to retrieve an explicit constructor, in languages that support an explicit **foreach** construct, it is simpler to use the looping construct directly in order to iterate through the rows in the data reader.
If you implement this method, it should return a new instance of <xref:System.Data.Common.DbEnumerator> or ensure that your enumerator returns <xref:System.Data.IDataRecord> objects.

Docs.typeparam: The type of the value to be returned.
Docs.summary: Gets the value of the specified column as the requested type.
Docs.returns: The value of the specified column.
Docs.exception:
The connection was dropped or closed during data retrieval.
-or-
The data reader was closed during data retrieval.
-or-
There is no data ready to be read (for example, the first hasn't been called, or it returned ).
-or-
The reader tried to read a previously-read column in sequential mode.
-or-
There was an asynchronous operation in progress. This applies to all Get* methods when running in sequential mode, as they could be called while reading a stream.
The column index is out of range.
The value returned by the database doesn't match or cannot be cast to .

Docs.summary: Asynchronously gets the value of the specified column as the requested type.

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Threading.Tasks.Task<T> GetFieldValueAsync<T> (int ordinal);
.method public hidebysig instance class System.Threading.Tasks.Task`1<!!T> GetFieldValueAsync<T>(int32 ordinal) cil managed
Public Function GetFieldValueAsync(Of T) (ordinal As Integer) As Task(Of T)
member this.GetFieldValueAsync : int -> System.Threading.Tasks.Task<'T>

Docs.typeparam: The type of the value to be returned.
Docs.summary: Asynchronously gets the value of the specified column as the requested type.
Docs.returns: A task whose contains the value of the specified column.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This asynchronous method is only needed to avoid blocking the calling thread when the reader is created in sequential mode.
If sequential mode isn't specified, all column values should become available in memory each time ReadAsync completes, and calling the synchronous version of the method shouldn't block the calling thread.
The default implementation of this asynchronous method invokes its synchronous counterpart and returns a completed Task, potentially blocking the calling thread.
Data providers that support [asynchronous programming](/dotnet/framework/data/adonet/asynchronous-programming) should override the default implementation using asynchronous I/O operations.
Other methods and properties of the DbDataReader object should not be invoked while the returned Task is not yet completed.

Docs.exception:
The connection was dropped or closed during data retrieval.
-or-
The data reader was closed during the data retrieval.
-or-
There is no data ready to be read (for example, the first hasn't been called, or it returned ).
-or-
Tried to read a previously-read column in sequential mode.
-or-
There was an asynchronous operation in progress. This applies to all Get_*_ methods when running in sequential mode, as they could be called while reading a stream.
The column index is out of range.
The value returned by the database doesn't match or cannot be cast to .

.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class System.Threading.Tasks.Task`1<!!T> GetFieldValueAsync<T>(int32 ordinal, valuetype System.Threading.CancellationToken cancellationToken) cil managed
Public Overridable Function GetFieldValueAsync(Of T) (ordinal As Integer, cancellationToken As CancellationToken) As Task(Of T)

abstract member GetFieldValueAsync : int * System.Threading.CancellationToken -> System.Threading.Tasks.Task<'T> override this.GetFieldValueAsync : int * System.Threading.CancellationToken -> System.Threading.Tasks.Task<'T>

Docs.typeparam: The type of the value to be returned.
Docs.param: A token to cancel the asynchronous operation.
Docs.summary: Asynchronously gets the value of the specified column as the requested type.
Docs.returns: A task whose contains the value of the specified column.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This asynchronous method is only needed to avoid blocking the calling thread when the reader is created in sequential mode.
If sequential mode isn't specified, all column values should become available in memory each time ReadAsync completes, and calling the synchronous version of the method shouldn't block the calling thread.
The default implementation of this asynchronous method invokes its synchronous counterpart and returns a completed Task, potentially blocking the calling thread. The default implementation also returns a cancelled task if passed an already cancelled cancellation token.
Data providers that support [asynchronous programming](/dotnet/framework/data/adonet/asynchronous-programming) should override the default implementation using asynchronous I/O operations.
This method accepts a cancellation token that can be used to request the operation to be cancelled early. Implementations may ignore this request.
Other methods and properties of the DbDataReader object should not be invoked while the returned Task is not yet completed.

Docs.exception:
The connection was dropped or closed during data retrieval.
-or-
The data reader was closed during the data retrieval.
-or-
There is no data ready to be read (for example, the first hasn't been called, or it returned ).
-or-
Tried to read a previously-read column in sequential mode.
-or-
There was an asynchronous operation in progress. This applies to all Get_*_ methods when running in sequential mode, as they could be called while reading a stream.
The column index is out of range.
The value returned by the database doesn't match or cannot be cast to .

Docs.summary: This is the asynchronous version of . Providers should override with an appropriate implementation. The can optionally be honored. The default implementation invokes the synchronous call and returns a completed task. The default implementation will return a cancelled task if passed an already cancelled . Exceptions thrown by will be communicated via the returned Task Exception property.
Docs.returns: A task representing the asynchronous operation.

Docs.summary: Gets a stream to retrieve data from the specified column.
Docs.returns: A stream.

remarks.format: ## Remarks <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader.GetStream%2A> only supports the retrieval of values that can be converted to byte arrays.

Docs.exception:
The connection was dropped or closed during the data retrieval.
-or-
The data reader is closed during the data retrieval.
-or-
There is no data ready to be read (for example, the first hasn't been called, or returned false).
-or-
The data reader tried to read a previously-read column in sequential mode.
-or-
There was an asynchronous operation in progress. This applies to all Get* methods when running in sequential mode, as they could be called while reading a stream.
The column index is out of range.
The specified column isn't a binary type that supports reading with a .

Docs.summary: When overridden in a derived class, gets a value that indicates whether the column contains nonexistent or missing values.
Docs.returns: if the specified column is equivalent to ; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks Call this method to check for null column values before calling the typed Get_*_ methods (for example, <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader.GetByte%2A>, <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader.GetChar%2A>, and so on) to avoid throwing an exception.

Docs.exception: The column index is out of range.

member this.IsDBNullAsync : int -> System.Threading.Tasks.Task<bool>

Docs.param: The zero-based column to be retrieved.
Docs.summary: Asynchronously gets a value that indicates whether the column contains non-existent or missing values.
Docs.returns: A whose property is if the specified column value is equivalent to or if it is not.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This asynchronous method is only needed to avoid blocking the calling thread when the reader is created in sequential mode.
If sequential mode isn't specified, all column values should become available in memory each time ReadAsync completes, and calling the synchronous version of the method shouldn't block the calling thread.
The default implementation of this asynchronous method invokes its synchronous counterpart and returns a completed Task, potentially blocking the calling thread.
Data providers that support [asynchronous programming](/dotnet/framework/data/adonet/asynchronous-programming) should override the default implementation using asynchronous I/O operations.
Other methods and properties of the DbDataReader object should not be invoked while the returned Task is not yet completed.

Docs.exception:
The connection was dropped or closed during the data retrieval.
-or-
The data reader is closed during the data retrieval.
-or-
There is no data ready to be read (for example, the first hasn't been called, or returned false).
-or-
Trying to read a previously read column in sequential mode.
-or-
There was an asynchronous operation in progress. This applies to all Get* methods when running in sequential mode, as they could be called while reading a stream.
The column index is out of range.

Public Overridable Function IsDBNullAsync (ordinal As Integer, cancellationToken As CancellationToken) As Task(Of Boolean)

public: virtual System::Threading::Tasks::Task<bool> ^ IsDBNullAsync(int ordinal, System::Threading::CancellationToken cancellationToken);

Docs.returns: A whose property is if the specified column value is equivalent to or if it is not.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This asynchronous method is only needed to avoid blocking the calling thread when the reader is created in sequential mode.
If sequential mode isn't specified, all column values should become available in memory each time ReadAsync completes, and calling the synchronous version of the method shouldn't block the calling thread.
The default implementation of this asynchronous method invokes its synchronous counterpart and returns a completed Task, potentially blocking the calling thread. The default implementation also returns a cancelled task if passed an already cancelled cancellation token.
Data providers that support [asynchronous programming](/dotnet/framework/data/adonet/asynchronous-programming) should override the default implementation using asynchronous I/O operations.
This method accepts a cancellation token that can be used to request the operation to be cancelled early. Implementations may ignore this request.
Other methods and properties of the DbDataReader object should not be invoked while the returned Task is not yet completed.

Docs.exception:
The connection was dropped or closed during the data retrieval.
-or-
The data reader is closed during the data retrieval.
-or-
There is no data ready to be read (for example, the first hasn't been called, or returned false).
-or-
Trying to read a previously read column in sequential mode.
-or-
There was an asynchronous operation in progress. This applies to all Get* methods when running in sequential mode, as they could be called while reading a stream.
The column index is out of range.

public: abstract property int RecordsAffected { int get(); };

Docs.summary: When overridden in a derived class, gets the number of rows changed, inserted, or deleted by execution of the SQL statement.
Docs.value: The number of rows changed, inserted, or deleted. -1 for SELECT statements; 0 if no rows were affected or the statement failed.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The `RecordsAffected` property is not set until all rows are read and you close the `DataReader`.

block.para: This property and should be implemented to return a value when the reader is closed.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual int VisibleFieldCount { get; }
.property instance int32 VisibleFieldCount
Public Overridable ReadOnly Property VisibleFieldCount As Integer
member this.VisibleFieldCount : int
public: virtual property int VisibleFieldCount { int get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the number of fields in the that are not hidden.
Docs.value: The number of fields that are not hidden.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This value is used to determine how many fields in the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader> are visible. For example, a SELECT on a partial primary key returns the remaining parts of the key as hidden fields. The hidden fields are always appended behind the visible fields.
